Award.AwardTitle: CCRI: ENS: Modernizing and Streamlining DeterLab Testbed Experimentation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This project modernizes the publicly available DeterLab cybersecurity testbed by: (1) updating the community research infrastructure (switches and nodes) to support large scale, virtualized experiments, (2) streamlining the experimentation process to broaden participation of new user communities. One third of the institutions using DeterLab today are community colleges and smaller universities, which lack dedicated research infrastructure. This new generation of Community Research Infrastructure will offer powerful assistance to level the playing field for the underserved research and student populations.<br/><br/>The project will be carried out through a groundbreaking program to: (1) modernize the community research infrastructure of the public DeterLab testbed for cybersecurity experimentation, and to (2) streamline the experimentation process to broaden participation of new user communities. Research infrastructure modernization will be achieved with three architectural changes: (1) replacing current, 15-year old network switches with modern whitebox switches, which support programmable software-defined networking (SDN) and Ethernet Virtual Private Network (EVPN) with Virtual Extensible LAN (VXLAN) dataplane encapsulation, (2) replacing all dated (over 10 years) old PC nodes with 144 high-density nodes, which support virtualization of many nodes on one physical node, (3) replacing current, outdated, testbed software, based on Emulab, with modular and modern Merge software. These changes will modernize the testbed, making it more robust, reliable, and self-sustainable, supporting many more users through resource virtualization. These changes will additionally enable users to perform large-scale experiments with reconfigurable topologies and across multiple testbeds.<br/><br/>The project will further streamline the experimentation process on the modernized DeterLab testbed by: (1) fully integrating several solutions for testbed experimentation (virtualization, traffic generators, orchestration software, malware experimentation environment, etc.), developed over the years, with the mainstream testbed software, documenting them and making them available to all users, (2) providing a set of experiment templates in several cybersecurity domains that users can start from and evolve to fit their needs; these templates will include the newly-integrated experimentation solutions, (3) offering live and recorded Webinars on monthly basis, and offering tutorials and demos at cybersecurity conferences and workshops, as well as diversity conferences and workshops, to attract new users to the modernized DeterLab testbed. Streamlining the experimentation process will make it easier for current users to design and perform experiments, and will attract and ease the on-boarding for new users. Community engagement and outreach activities will ensure that existing and new users provide input to the modernization project. Additional information on DeterLab can be found at https://deter-project.org/<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This DeterLab modernization project provided groundbreaking enhancements and advanced sustainment for a critical open cybersecurity research infrastructure testbed. The publicly available DeterLab Cybersecurity testbed was modernized through the addition of new state-of-the-art hardware systems and we have vastly improved and streamlined experimentation process through the transition to the Merge testbed control software.  Along with the upgrades to the hardware and software research infrastructure, the project broadened the participation of new user communities. The original DeterLab testbed has served cybersecurity research and education communities for 20 years with support from the NSF, the DHS, and DARPA. DeterLab has been used by 389 research projects from 278 institutions worldwide, resulting in hundreds of publications, and at least thirty PhD and MS theses. One-third of the institutions using DeterLab today are community colleges and smaller universities, which lack dedicated research infrastructure. DeterLab is instrumental in helping these smaller institutions perform cutting edge research in cybersecurity, and is essential for supporting hands-on cybersecurity education in more than 140 institutions.

 

The infrastructure modernization was achieved with three architectural changes: (1) replaced 15-year old network switches with modern whitebox switches, which support programmable software-defined networking (SDN) and Ethernet Virtual Private Network (EVPN) with Virtual Extensible LAN (VXLAN) data-plane encapsulation, (2) the oldest experimental nodes were replaced with 144 high-density nodes, which support virtualization of many nodes on one physical node, (3) in conjunction with the modernization of the hardware we transitioned the testbed control software to the modular and modern Merge software. These changes significantly modernized the former DeterLab testbed, making it more robust, reliable, and self-sustainable, while supporting many more simultaneous users through resource virtualization. Furthermore, these changes enabled users to perform large-scale experiments with reconfigurable topologies.   

Intellectual Merit. The enhancements produced under this project benefited the CISE community by enabling large-scale, easier experimentation on modern hardware, and by supporting many simultaneous research users. The hardware and software modernization made the testbed more stable and removed longstanding experiment allocation failure use cases.   This enhanced user experience and more importantly provided the ability for the user community to allocate large-scale experiments more often and more reliably. Taken together these changes enabled smoother and more rapid experimentation for research and education users, and thus helped advance CISE research.

Broader Impact. The research and education enabled by the Deterlab testbed has had wide-ranging impact in the CISE research community, leading to more than 1,400 publications and more than thirty MS and PhD theses and educating many cybersecurity researchers and professionals. DeterLab educational impact comes from its extensive use helping to educate more than 20,000 students from over 140 institutions. The majority of the research and education users come from underserved communities – community colleges and lower-tier universities, with little opportunity for research. This modernization project’s enhancements continue to further impact the CISE research and education community and to increase diversification efforts. Overall, these enhancements resulted in increased accessibility for cyber experimentation and enabled faster innovation in the CISE community. The DeterLab modernization project has installed the new hardware and software and our team engaged in extensive outreach activities. This project continues to further diversify DeterLab’s user community and broaden participation in CISE research. The project also continues to further attract education users and create a better-prepared workforce in cybersecurity.
